The Browder bracket

Apr 21, 2020

In this post, I would like to talk about a construction of the Browder bracket on -algebras. This post is a topological version of the equivalence between factorization algebras and chiral algebras due to Beilinson and Drinfeld.

Recall that an -algebra (in spectra, or any presentable -category, really, but we’ll only care about spectra) is a factorizable constructible cosheaf of spectra on . Constructibility here refers to constructibility with respect to the cardinality stratification. Factorizability means that if is a finite subset, then the canonical map is an equivalence. The fact that is a cosheaf on implies the following: if is a finite subset and denotes the tautological map, then the (exceptional) pullback of along the diagonal is equivalent to . The factorizability condition means that there is an equivalence between the pullback of to and the pullback of (which lives over ) to .

I am being pretty noncanonical here, writing and , etc.; but I’m just doing this for ease of exposition.

The idea is that as pairs of points of (viewed as a point of ), which give rise to sections of , collide, the identification of on the diagonal with tells you how to multiply these sections. We’re supposed to think of as the -algebra.

So, let’s let denote the (open) inclusion of the diagonal. Also let and . Then we have the recollement cofiber sequence

There is an equivalence . There is also an equivalence , so we get a map

Composing with the canonical map now produces a map

This map is the Browder bracket for -algebras, and it satisfies the Lie algebra axioms (antisymmetry + Jacobi identity). More succintly, if , then we get a map

and hence a map , which makes an algebra over the Lie operad.

As mentioned above, this discussion is the topological analogue (over , at least) of the equivalence due to Beilinson and Drinfeld between chiral algebras and factorization algebras: given a factorization algebra as above, we get out the chiral algebra . What is the other direction in topology? Namely, given a Lie algebra, how do we get out an -algebra? A very simple description of this is as follows (and this only works in characteristic zero): the above construction (Browder/Lie from -algebra) gives a map of operads . The adjoint to this functor constructs an -algebra from a Lie algebra.

By the way, one thing that I would like to find a reference for is a precise discussion about the relationship between Beilinson-Drinfeld factorization algebras and -algebras. I’ve only found sources which give analogies… I’ll write up something that I think is true in the next post, though.
